game.name: 3-SPOT
game.board: The game is played on a 3x3 grid. The bottom 3 cells are point squares.[img src="a.svg" alt="a" width="300" height="300"]
game.pieces: There are three rectangular pieces that each shall cover a 1-by-2 area of the board. The first player controls the blue piece. The second player controls the red piece. Both players control the white (neutral) piece.
game.tomove: Move your colored piece (whichever of the blue or red piece you control) so that it covers a 1-by-2 area of the board such that at least one of the squares newly covered by your colored piece was not covered by it immediately before you moved it. Count the number of point squares covered by your colored piece, and add it to your score. Then, move the white piece such that it coveres a 1-by-2 area of the board such that at least one of the squares newly covered by the white piece was not covered by it immediately before you moved it.
game.towin: Have fewer than 6 points while your opponent has at least 12 points, or have at least 12 points while your opponent has at least 6 points.
game.rules: Both players' scores begin at 0. The pieces are initially arranged as follows: [img src="b.svg" alt="a" width="300" height="300"] As an example, suppose it is the first (blue) player's turn at the following position:[img src="c.svg" alt="a" width="300" height="300"] The blue player first moves the blue piece. The blue player may decide, for example to move the blue piece to reach the following state:[img src="d.svg" alt="a" width="300" height="300"] We count the number of point squares that the blue piece covers after the blue piece has moved. The blue piece covers one point square, so the blue player gains one point. Then the blue player must move the white piece.[img src="e.svg" alt="a" width="300" height="300"] Point squares covered by the white piece do not count toward either player's score. It is now the red player's turn.

strategy.name: General
strategy.description: Interesting strategies can arise in this game because of the nature of the win condition. At certain points you may want to score as many points as you can, but at others you may want to force the opponent to score points while you seek to avoid scoring.

variant.name: Misere
variant.description: Either (1) stay below 6 points and force your opponent to score at least 12 points or (2) score 12 points while keeping your opponent under 6 points.

variant.name: Optional Neutral Piece Move
variant.description: A player may choose to not move the neutral piece after their turn.

variant.name: Point Squares
variant.description: Any grid square can be a point square.

variant.name: Point Winning Condition
variant.description: The winning condition can be defined according to an arbitrary function that takes the players' scores and assigns the score pair as either a win for the first player, a win for the second player, or not yet a win.

references.reference: Edward De Bono. "The 3 Spot Game." Edward De Bono's Web. < http://www.edwdebono.com/debono/3spot.htm >.
